turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Greco Deco.
turn.2: Greco Deco Greco Deco is a term coined by Washington, DC based art historian James M. Goode to describe a style of art and architecture popularized in the late 1920s and 1930s.
turn.3: What are some of the characteristics of the style?
turn.4: Arising out of the Beaux-Arts tradition, Greco Deco combined Greek and Roman traditions with those of the then fashionable Art Deco.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: The style is also referred to as Stripped Classical for its simpler appearance compared to neoclassical architecture.
turn.7: What about the details of the style?
turn.8: Greco Deco architecture frequently expressed itself in a rather severe Greco-Roman facade decorated with deco styles shallow reliefs and/or deco styled interior decoration featuring murals, tile mosaics and sculpture.
turn.9: What other elements were used to create this style?
turn.10: A common motif among Greco Deco architecture is the use of stylized or simplified pilasters.
turn.12: The style was the almost-official style of many federal and local government buildings in the United States from the mid-1920s until World War II, and frequently overlaps with the style that architectural historian David Gebhard terms "WPA Moderne."
